paper_title: VisOnlyQA: Large Vision Language Models Still Struggle with Visual Perception of Geometric Information

sections.title: Abstract
sections.content: Errors in understanding visual information in images (i.e., visual perception errors) remain a major source of mistakes in Large Vision Language Models (LVLMs). While further analysis is essential, there is a deficiency in datasets for evaluating the visual perception of LVLMs. In this work, we introduce VisOnlyQA, a new dataset designed to directly evaluate the visual perception capabilities of LVLMs on questions about geometric and numerical information in scientific figures. Our dataset enables us to analyze the visual perception of LVLMs for fine-grained visual information, independent of other capabilities such as reasoning. The evaluation set of VisOnlyQA includes 1,200 multiple-choice questions in 12 tasks on four categories of figures. We also provide synthetic training data consisting of 70k instances. Our experiments on VisOnlyQA highlight the following findings: (i) 20 LVLMs we evaluate, including GPT-4o and Gemini 1.5 Pro, work poorly on the visual perception tasks in VisOnlyQA, while human performance is nearly perfect. (ii) Fine-tuning on synthetic training data demonstrates the potential for enhancing the visual perception of LVLMs, but observed improvements are limited to certain tasks and specific models. (iii) Stronger language models improve the visual perception of LVLMs. In summary, our experiments suggest that both training data and model architectures should be improved to enhance the visual perception capabilities of LVLMs. The datasets, code, and model responses are provided at https://github.com/psunlpgroup/VisOnlyQA.

Related Work Large Vision Language Models. Recent LVLMs often consist of vision transformers (ViT) [14] and large language models [56, 60], which are jointly trained on vision language tasks such as image captioning and visual question answering [2, 38, 41, 72]. Powered by the multi-modal pre-training on transformers, various open source [5, 11 13, 41, 42, 55, 71, 80] and proprietary [3, 20, 57] LVLMs have been developed in recent years. Several studies also propose models for specific applications, such as mathematical reasoning [78], chart understanding [40, 52], medical images [36], and text-rich image understanding [79]. Benchmarks for Multi-modal Reasoning on Scientific Figures. Various datasets that include questions about scientific figures have been proposed in the domains of mathematical reasoning [7, 8, 23, 46, 50], chart understanding [28, 51, 54], and academic exams [48, 49, 74]. Although they are popular benchmarks for recent LVLMs [3, 57, 59], questions in those datasets often require expert-level reasoning and knowledge, less focusing on visual perception. Moreover, recent studies [75, 77] point out that many questions in recent datasets provide too much information in text Benchmarks for Visual Perception Capabilities. Various datasets have been proposed to evaluate the visual perception capabilities of LVLMs on general figures. Several datasets target evaluating LVLMs on specific visual perception tasks, such as OCR [9, 43, 64], depth estimation [18], and counting [26, 65]. However, popular datasets for evaluating visual perception on general images [4, 16, 21, 24, 35, 44, 70] often evaluate relatively less fine-grained understanding of visual information in images, such as overall scene understanding. This is potentially due to the difficulty of creating questions about detailed information on general images. In this work, we target scientific and synthetic figures because they allow us to annotate objective questions about detailed visual information. Several studies have also evaluated the visual perception of LVLMs on scientific figures. CharXiv [67] includes questions for evaluating the perception capabilities on charts. However, it often targets relatively easy tasks, such as What is its title. HallusionBench [22] shows that LVLMs exhibit poor visual perception of misleading figures such as illusive geometric shapes. Our work, in contrast, focuses on images and questions from more natural distribution. Fu et al. [17] evaluate visual perception by assessing the performance gaps when providing figures and text that include identical information. VisOnlyQA Dataset We introduce VisOnlyQA, new dataset designed to directly evaluate the visual perception capabilities of LVLMs on questions about the geometric and numerical information of scientific figures. Each instance of VisOnlyQA consists of figure, multiple-choice question, and answer label. As in Table 2 and Figure 3, VisOnlyQA includes 12 subtasks on figures in four categories: geometric shapes, chemical structures, charts, and 3D shapes. 3.1. Motivation Visual perception errors are still major source of mistakes in LVLMs [74, 77]. However, there is lack of datasets for analyzing the visual perception capabilities of LVLMs, as in Figure 1 and Table 1. Popular datasets for evaluating recent LVLMs often include tasks that require multiple capabilities, such as reasoning and knowledge [50, 74]. (1a) They put less focus on visual perception and (1b) cannot directly evaluate visual perception independent from other capabilities. (2) While there exist datasets designed for evaluating visual perception [4, 21, 24, 35], they often target an understanding of less fine-grained visual information on general images, such as scene understanding. We introduce VisOnlyQA to directly evaluate the visual perception capabilities of LVLMs in detail. For this purpose, we target questions about geometric and numerical information in scientific and synthetic figures. This approach 4 enables us to (1) avoid questions that demand other capabilities, such as reasoning and knowledge, allowing for direct assessment of visual perception, and (2) design objective questions about fine-grained visual information. 3.2. Sources of Figures VisOnlyQA includes two types of figures: Real and Synthetic. The Real figures are from existing datasets. We use figures in existing popular datasets to evaluate whether LVLMs truly understand images in those datasets. It also ensures that images are from natural distributions and not adversarially designed. The Synthetic figures are automatically generated. The primary purpose of synthetic figures is to provide large-scale training data to analyze finetuned models. In addition, they ensure that there is no bias caused by human annotations because both images and questions are automatically generated. Real Figures. We use figures from popular datasets in three domains: geometric shapes in MathVista [50], which includes Geometry3K [46], GeoQA+ [6], GEOS [61], and UniGeo [8], chemistry figures in MMMU [74], and charts in ChartQA [51] and CharXiv [67]. Synthetic Figures. For geometric shapes, we create new dataset, SyntheticGeometry, by generating geometric shapes by writing Python scripts based on an open source project [34] reproducing AlphaGeometry [63]. For 3D shapes, we use CLEVR [27] and SuperCLEVR [39]. 3.3. Questions For Real Figures Human Annotation. We manually annotate questions and answers for ten sub-tasks about the Real figures. We provide question templates and instructions to annotators, and each question-answer pair is annotated by one annotator. The annotators are PhD students specializing in natural language processing. For Synthetic Figures Synthetic Questions. We generate synthetic questions using the metadata of the synthetic figures and question templates, as in Figure 4. For geometric shapes, we use the metadata in SyntheticGeometry, including the positions of points and lines. We write Python scripts to calculate geometric information Figure 4. For 3D shapes, we write Python scripts to generate question-answer pairs about the relative sizes of objects in CLEVR (3D-Size) and angles between objects in SuperCLEVR (3D-Angle) using the metadata in CLEVR (positions and sizes) and SuperCLEVR (positions and angles). 3.4. Data Split VisOnlyQA includes three splits: Eval-Real, EvalSynthetic, and Train. Eval-Real includes 500 instances for ten sub-tasks in three categories of figures from existing datasets (geometry, chemistry, and charts). Eval-Synthetic and Train include 700 and 70k instances for seven sub-tasks in two categories of synthetic figures (geometry and 3D). 3.5. Data Analysis Geometric Shapes. Table 3 shows statistics of geometric shapes in VisOnlyQA. For Real figures, we manually annotate 24 figures to get the statistics. For Synthetic figures, we calculate the statistics of all images using the metadata. Geometric shapes in the Synthetic data include more points, lines, and circles, with larger standard deviations, suggesting that they are more complex and diverse. Label Distribution. To ensure that the labels in our dataset are balanced, we instructed the annotators to make an equal number of questions for each option and add negative version of the questions for all true or false questions (e.g., There is triangle ABC in this figure and There is no triangle ABC in this figure). Finally, we shuffled the options to remove biases caused by the order of the options. Human Performance. To verify the annotation quality and evaluate human performance, we provide randomly sampled questions to three new annotators (300 instances in total) for the Real split and two new annotators (140 instances in total) for the Synthetic split. The average human performance is 93.5% and 95.0% in accuracy, as in Table 4a, showing that the dataset quality is high and the tasks in VisOnlyQA are easy and unambiguous for humans. 4. We hypothesize that the current LVLMs have weak visual perception capabilities because the training data of current LVLMs do not include sufficient amount of data that requires detailed visual perception. To verify this hypothesis, we evaluate LVLMs finetuned on VisOnlyQA-Train. Settings. We fine-tune InternVL2 (4B, 8B) [12, 59], Qwen2-VL (2B, 7B) [66], and Phi-3.5-Vision [1, 55] on Figure 6. Errors in chain-of-thought reasoning by LVLMs on VisOnlyQA-Eval-Real. Almost all errors are visual perception errors, verifying that our dataset directly evaluates visual perception. We manually annotate the error categories. Each response can include multiple categories of errors. Chain-of-Thought Does Not Consistently Improve Performance. Figure 5 shows performance improvement by using chain-of-thought reasoning, indicating that chain-ofthought does not consistently improve the performance of LVLMs on VisOnlyQA-Eval-Real and harms the performance in some cases. This result differs from observations on existing datasets for vision-language reasoning tasks, where chain-of-thought largely improves the performance of LVLMs [10, 69, 77]. This result is consistent with our claim that our dataset directly evaluates the visual perception capabilities and does not require reasoning. 7 Figure 7. Accuracy after fine-tuning on VisOnlyQA-Train. We evaluate the fine-tuned models on VisOnlyQA-Eval-Synthetic, which is generated from the same distribution as the train data, and VisOnlyQA-Eval-Real, which includes images from different distributions. The numbers above the bars represent the improvements from the original models. More details are in Table 10. each task in VisOnlyQA-Train (7 tasks in total) and evaluate on Eval-Synthetic (in-distribution; figures from the same distribution as the Train data) and Eval-Real (outof-distribution). To evaluate the maximum possible performance, we fine-tune each model in single-task setting on 10k training data. In total, we fine-tune seven different models independently for each LVLM. We use prompts without chain-of-thought. Refer to Appendix for detailed settings. Improvement by Fine-tuning Depends on Tasks. Figure 7 shows that fine-tuning often improves performance on VisOnlyQA, especially on in-distribution (Synthetic) data. Specifically, all models achieve near-perfect performance in 3D-Size after fine-tuning, and InternVL2-8B and Qwen2-VL-7B show large improvement even on the out-of-distribution (Real) figures in Geometry-Length. This result partially verifies our hypothesis that training data for existing LVLMs are insufficient and indicates that our approach of using synthetic training data has the potential to improve the visual perception of LVLMs. However, fine-tuning almost does not improve performance even on the in-distribution (Synthetic) data in 3DAngle on all models we evaluate. In addition, the improvement on the in-distribution (Synthetic) figures do not generalize well to the out-of-distribution (Real) figures on Geometry-Angle and Geometry-Area. This result indicates that fine-tuning does not always improve visual perception, depending on the properties of target tasks. Performance of Fine-tuned Models Depends on Model Sizes. We also observe that larger models often work better even after fine-tuning; InternVL2-8B and Qwen2-VL7B perform better than smaller models in GeometryLength and Geometry-Area. This result suggests that model architectures largely influence visual perception, even when fine-tuning datasets for target tasks are available.

We also evaluate models fine-tuned on our synthetic training data designed to improve visual perception. We observe that fine-tuning does not always improve visual perception, and the performance is largely affected by task properties and model architectures, even after fine-tuning. In addition, our experiments suggest that language models of LVLMs influence visual perception, and strong language models are needed to properly process visual information encoded by ViT. This work reveals that LVLMs still do not have strong visual perception capabilities, and we need to improve both training data and model architectures for better visual perception.
